Variations.condition: Community-acquired in previously healthy patient, (excluding abdominal or pelvic source)
Variations.organisms: Staph. aureus, Strep. pneumoniae, Neisseria. meningitidis, Step. pyogenes (Group A strep), Occasionally Gram-negative bacilli.
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds
Plus
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis):
Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Plus
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Variations.comments:
Perform full septic screen. Always take blood cultures first (minimum 2 sets).
Refer to Connolly Hospital Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist if in doubt or in setting of penicillin anaphylaxis

Variations.condition: Community-acquired if intra- abdominal source suspected
Variations.organisms: Predominantly Gram negatives and anaerobes Enterococci may also feature
Variations.antimicrobial:
Co-amoxiclav 1.2g iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od (based on patient history, previous antibiotic use, clinical assessment, etc.)
Or
Amoxicillin 1g iv qds
Plus
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Plus
Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime 1.5g iv tds
Plus
Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis): Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.comments:
Perform full septic screen
Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist if necessary
Send intra-operative samples (preferably pus not swabs) for culture if surgical intervention performed

Variations.organisms: Varies: Antimicrobial resistant gram- negative bacilli and meticillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) more likely
Variations.antimicrobial:
Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od (base treatment choice on patient history, previous antibiotic use, microbiology results, clinical assessment, etc.)
Variations.comments: Always take blood cultures first. Empiric treatment guided by previous antimicrobial treatment and culture results to date (review MRSA status and consider addition of Vancomycin if known to be colonised with MRSA)

Variations.antimicrobial: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd PLUS Gentamicin 1mg/kg iv bd
Variations.alternative: Penicillin allergy or MRSA as suspected causative pathogen: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd PLUS Gentamicin 1mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments: Investigations:3 sets of blood cultures before antibiotics are started (label as ?Infective Endocarditis). If blood cultures remain sterile consider serology for Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) and Bartonella species. If negative consider serology for Brucella spp., Mycoplasma spp, Chlamydia spp. and Legionella spp. ESR/CRP, FBC, MSU, CXR, Echo

Variations.antimicrobial: Amoxicillin 2g iv 4 hourly PLUS Gentamicin 1mg/kg iv bd
Variations.alternative: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd PLUS Gentamicin 1mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments: Investigations:3 sets of blood cultures before antibiotics are started (label as ?Infective Endocarditis). If blood cultures remain sterile consider serology for Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) and Bartonella species. If negative consider serology for Brucella spp., Mycoplasma spp, Chlamydia spp. and Legionella spp. ESR/CRP, FBC, MSU, CXR, Echo

Variations.organisms: Coagulase negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, Viridans type streptococci
Variations.antimicrobial:
Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd PLUS Gentamicin 1mg/kg iv bd PLUS Rifampicin 300-600mg PO bd

When given in divided daily dose, target gentamicin pre dose level of ≤1 mg/L and post-dose levels 3-5 mg/L.

Target vancomycin pre dose level of 15-20 mg/L
Variations.comments: Investigations:3 sets of blood cultures before antibiotics are started (label as ?Infective Endocarditis). If blood cultures remain sterile consider serology for Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) and Bartonella species. If negative consider serology for Brucella spp., Mycoplasma spp, Chlamydia spp. and Legionella spp. ESR/CRP, FBC, MSU, CXR, Echo

Variations.condition:
Probable bacterial meningitis (Adults).
However if Listeria monocytogenes suspected (immunocompromised, elderly, pregnancy, etc) see additional info in Antimicrobial section.
Variations.antimicrobial:
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds PLUS Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd

Consider addition of Dexamethasone phosphate IV 0.15mg/kg qds for 4 days. Ideally steroids should be given either before or at the time of antibiotic administration – if in doubt discuss with Consultant Microbiologist.
Avoid dexamethasone if:
1) Already received antibiotics
2) Septic shock
3) Post neurosurgical meningitis
4) Immunosuppressed patients

Additional Info

Add Amoxicillin 2g iv 4 hrly

Duration (IV therapy only): Meningococcal meningitis: 7 days Pneumococcal meningitis: 10-14 days
Listeria meningitis: 21 days
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy: Meropenem 2g iv tds
PLUS Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures, CSF, EDTA bottle (meningococcal & pneumococcal PCR), throat swab

Commence IV antibiotics as soon as possible. Do not wait for CSF sampling if delay expected.

Steroid therapy has been shown to be most beneficial in adults with pneumococcal meningitis.

Refer to Connolly Hospital Infection Prevention and Control manual re infection prevention and control precautions and patient placement.

Inform Public Health doctors

Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist in all cases

Variations.antimicrobial: Usually no treatment indicated – if in doubt discuss with Consultant Microbiologist
Variations.comments:
Investigations:Send CSF for viral PCR

Other causes of lymphocytic CSF include:TB, Cryptococcus, Borreliosis, Leptospirosis, Mycoplasma, Syphilis, Listeria.

Variations.organisms: Herpes simplex, Varicella zoster, Mumps, Enterovirus
Variations.antimicrobial:
Aciclovir 10 mg/kg iv tds

Duration: 14-21 days
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Send CSF for herpes simplex virus, varicella zoster virus, mumps and enterovirus PCR
Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist in all cases

Variations.antimicrobial: Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist in all cases.
Benzylpenicillin 1.2-2.4g iv qds <u>or</u> Amoxicillin 500mg po tds
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy:</u> Doxycycline 100mg po bd or Clindamycin 300-450 mg po qds

Variations.organisms:
Group A ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus (Strep pyogenes)
Staph. aureus
Variations.antimicrobial:
Mild (not systemically unwell) Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds Duration: 7 days

Moderate (signs of systemic toxicity or progressive cellulitis) Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Duration: 10-14 days

Severe (rapidly progressive cellulitis with severe sepsis/shock) Discuss with Consultant Microbiologist as possibility of deeper infection such as necrotising fasciitis should be considered Duration: 10-14 days
Variations.alternative:
Mild Penicillin allergy (non-anaphylaxis): Cephalexin 500mg po tds

MRSA positive (or penicillin anaphylaxis): Doxycycline 100mg po bd or Clindamycin 450 mg po qds (if susceptible - check with microbiology laboratory)

ModerateMRSA positive or penicillin allergy: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures (if systemic features), swab if exudates present, check CRP/ESR/WBC, demarcate on patients skin outer border of cellulitis, check MRSA status if in-patient or recent healthcare contact

Note flucloxacillin has activity against both meticillin sensitive S. aureus and ß- Haemolytic streptococci so addition of benzylpenicillin is not indicated Clindamycin associated with increased risk of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhoea – reserve its use to defined indications as set out in these guidelines

Variations.condition: Gas gangrene, Necrotising fasciitis and other serious soft tissue infection
Variations.organisms: Polymicrobial including Group A ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus, Anaerobic bacteria (e.g. Clostridium perfringens), etc.
Variations.antimicrobial: Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist
Variations.comments: Systemic toxicity, severe pain, swelling, crepitus and necrosis are clinical signs. Seek urgent advice from surgeons and microbiologist. Operative specimens for culture essential.

Variations.antimicrobial: Topical antiseptic solutions eg Chlorhexidine or Povidone Iodine and dressings usually sufficient. Topical antibiotics are not recommended
Variations.comments: Clinically non-infected ulcers should not be cultured Systemic antimicrobials only indicated if evidence of cellulitis or systemic infection. Use previous culture results as a guide.

Variations.condition: Surgical wound infections: Following Clean Surgery
Variations.antimicrobial: Treat as cellulitis MILD, MODERATE or SEVERE as above
Variations.alternative: Treat as cellulitis MILD, MODERATE or SEVERE as above
Variations.comments: Antibiotics may not be necessary: surgical drainage and/or topical antiseptics may be sufficient.

Variations.organisms: S. aureus, Gram negative bacilli, Streptococci, Anaerobes
Variations.antimicrobial:
Co-Amoxiclav 1.2g iv tds

OR

Amoxicillin 1g iv tds Plus Gentamicin 5mg/kg iv od Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds

Duration: 5-7 days
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis): Cefuroxime 1.5g iv tds Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis): Contact Consultant Microbiologist to discuss
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures, swab if exudates present, CRP/ESR/WBC

Investigations: Blood cultures, swab if exudates present, CRP/ESR/WBC

Pus or tissue are more useful than swabs.

Variations.organisms: Wide range of flora including Pasteurella multocida and Capnocytophaga canimorsus
Variations.antimicrobial: Co-amoxiclav 625mg po tds Duration: 5-7 days
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime axetil 500 mg po bd Plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis) Doxycycline 200mg po STAT then 100mg po bd plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds
Variations.comments:
Assess tetanus and rabies risk. Antibiotic prophylaxis may not be indicated for all cases.
Antibiotic prophylaxis advised for – puncture wound, bite involving hand, foot, face, joint, tendon, ligament, immunocompromised, diabetic, elderly, asplenic.

Variations.organisms: Wide range of mouth flora including viridans streptococci, staphylococci and Haemophilus spp.
Variations.antimicrobial: Co-amoxiclav 625mg po tds Duration: 5-7 days
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime axetil 500 mg po bd Plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis) Doxycycline 200mg po STAT then 100mg po bd plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds
Variations.comments: Antibiotic prophylaxis advised. Risk assess for relevant blood borne viruses e.g. hepatitis B/C, HIV

Variations.organisms: Predominantly gram- positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococus aureus, Beta haemolytic streptococci)
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds
Duration: 7 days
Variations.comments: Tissue or pus specimen from ulcer to be sent for culture and sensitivity (here and below rationalise treatment based on c+s). Always review previous culture results as this will guide therapy. Management includes wound care – clean, debride (antibiotics do not penetrate necrotic tissue) and offload pressure. Discuss care with endocrinology team

Variations.condition: Infected deep ulcer/ infected ulcer with mild (<2cm) cellulitis
Variations.organisms: Predominantly gram- positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococus aureus, Beta haemolytic streptococci)*
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds*

Duration: 10-14 days (duration depends on extent of tissue injury involvement, adequacy of debridement and wound vasculature)
Variations.alternative:
Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Discuss with microbiologist
*If chronic ulcers, recent antibiotic use and foot ischaemia or gangrene consider polymicrobial aetiology and need for co-amoxiclav instead of flucloxacillin
Variations.comments:
As above
Patient may require IV antibiotics.
Contact microbiologist to discuss risk assessment regarding ciprofloxacin use in case of suspected pseudomonal infection.

Variations.condition: Infected foot ulcer with severe (>2cm) cellulitis
Variations.antimicrobial: Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds. Duration: 14 days (duration depends on extent of tissue injury involvement, adequacy of debridement and wound vasculature)
Variations.alternative: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds.
Variations.comments:
Ulcer debridement and send tissue sample or pus to microbiology.

If the patient has a past history of C. difficile contact the microbiologist regarding an alternative to ciprofloxacin for antibiotic therapy.

Variations.condition: Infected foot ulcer with suspected osteomyelitis
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds.
Duration: 8 weeks – 3 months (duration depends on acute or chronic presentation).
Variations.alternative: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.comments:
Orthopaedic consultation regarding the need for bone biopsy and bone culture and in the setting of chronic osteomyelitis the need for bone debridement
Discuss treatment plan with microbiologist

Variations.organisms: S. aureus, ß- Haemolytic Streptococcus (predominantly Groups A, C and G)
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Sodium Fusidate 500mg po tds
Duration: 6 weeks minimum but will vary. A minimum of two weeks intravenous treatment is recommended. Discuss with microbiologist re oral switch
Variations.comments:
Sodium fusidate interacts with statins and there is a significant risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis. Concurrent use will require either temporary discontinuation of statin or close medical supervision. Consult pharmacy for advice.

Investigations: Blood cultures, CRP/ESR/WBC, send synovial fluid for urate and pyrophosphate crystals

Deep bone specimens/Joint aspiration (prior to treatment if possible) are essential to establish diagnosis and further management. Do not rely on the results of superficial swabs of ulcers to identify the cause(s) of the bone infection Consider gonococcal septic arthritis in young adult (send STD screen and contact Consultant Microbiologist)
Further therapy should be discussed with Consultant Microbiologist

Variations.organisms: S. aureus ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus (predominantly Groups A, C and G)
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Sodium Fusidate 500mg po tds
Duration: 4 weeks minimum but will vary. A minimum of two weeks intravenous treatment is recommended. Discuss with microbiologist re oral switch therapy
Variations.comments:
Sodium fusidate interacts with statins and there is a significant risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis. Concurrent use will require either temporary discontinuation of statin or close medical supervision. Consult pharmacy for advice.

Investigations: Blood cultures, CRP/ESR/WBC, send synovial fluid for urate and pyrophosphate crystals

Deep bone specimens/Joint aspiration (prior to treatment if possible) are essential to establish diagnosis and further management. Do not rely on the results of superficial swabs of ulcers to identify the cause(s) of the bone infection Consider gonococcal septic arthritis in young adult (send STD screen and contact Consultant Microbiologist)
Further therapy should be discussed with Consultant Microbiologist

Variations.condition: Subacute Osteomyelitis/Septic arthritis in Elderly or Chronically Debilitated Patient eg vertebral osteomyelitis
Variations.organisms:
S. aureus ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus (predominantly Groups A, C and G)
Also
Gram negative bacilli
Variations.antimicrobial:
Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd

Duration: Long term therapy (8 weeks-3 months) may be required
Variations.comments:
Sodium fusidate interacts with statins and there is a significant risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis. Concurrent use will require either temporary discontinuation of statin or close medical supervision. Consult pharmacy for advice.

Investigations: Blood cultures, CRP/ESR/WBC, send synovial fluid for urate and pyrophosphate crystals

Deep bone specimens/Joint aspiration (prior to treatment if possible) are essential to establish diagnosis and further management. Do not rely on the results of superficial swabs of ulcers to identify the cause(s) of the bone infection Consider gonococcal septic arthritis in young adult (send STD screen and contact Consultant Microbiologist)
Bone Sampling essential
Further therapy should be discussed with Consultant Microbiologist

Variations.organisms: Extensive range of organisms (including mycobacteria species)
Variations.antimicrobial:
Guided by Culture results

Duration: Long term therapy (i.e. 3-6 months may be required)
Variations.comments:
Investigations: Blood cultures, CRP/ESR/WBC, bone biopsy for C&S, AFB & mycobacterial culture
• Bone biopsy – do not rely on the results of superficial swabs of ulcers to identify the cause(s) of the bone infection.
• In patients with infected foot ulcers, multiple bacterial species may be implicated. It is ESSENTIAL therefore to identify the microbiological cause(s).

Variations.organisms: Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococci spp most common
Variations.antimicrobial:
Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
PLUS Rifampicin 450mg po bd

Duration:Long term therapy

Always contact Consultant Microbiologist to discuss.
Variations.comments:
Investigations:Blood cultures, CRP/ESR/WBC.
Review therapy when culture results available

May require removal of prosthesis
